original_data.question: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand. The stiffness is worse at the end of the day. She recently retired after working for 28 years as a typist at a data entry firm. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the first metacarpophalangeal joint and the distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender nodules are palpated over the 2nd and 4th distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. An x-ray of her right hand shows narrowing of the interphalangeal joint spaces with subchondral sclerosis and osteophytes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?

options.A: Bacterial infection of the joint space
options.C: Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal precipitation in the joints

model_response:
The patient has osteoarthritis. The most common form of osteoarthritis is primary osteoarthritis, which is a degenerative disease of joints. The prevalence of osteoarthritis increases with age. It is most common in the knee, hip, spine, and hand joints. The weight-bearing joints are particularly susceptible. The process begins with fissuring and cracks in the articular cartilage. Subchondral bone responds by increasing the density of its bone, forming osteophytes. Cystic areas develop under the joint surface and become filled with fibrous tissue and inflammatory cells. The inflammatory component of osteoarthritis is minimal, however, and most of the pain is a result of damage to the articular cartilage. The other choices are not likely causes of this patient's condition.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>
